quotes: Assumed office 24 June 2013
Aide to the President of Russia In office 22 May 2012 – 24 June 2013
Minister of Economic Development In office 24 September 2007 – 21 May 2012
She was President Vladimir Putin's economic adviser from May 2012 to June 2013
after serving as the minister of economic development from September 2007 to May 2012
Nabiullina was born in Ufa, Bashkir ASSR, on 29 October 1963
Moscow State University Faculty of Economics in 1986.
selected for the 2007 Yale World Fellows program.
Between 1991 and 1994, Nabiullina worked at the USSR Science and Industry Union and its successor, the Russian Union of Industrialists and Entrepreneurs.
In 1994, she moved to the Ministry for Economic Development and Trade, where she rose to the level of deputy minister by 1997;
In 1994, she moved to the Ministry for Economic Development and Trade, where she rose to the level of deputy minister by 1997;
she left the ministry in 1998.
before returning to the Ministry for Economic Development and Trade as first deputy in 2000.
Between 2003 and her September 2007 appointment as minister, she chaired the Center for Strategic Development as well as an advisory committee preparing for Russia's 2006 presidency of the G8.
Russian President Putin appointed Nabiullina to the post of minister of economic development and trade on 24 September 2007, replacing Gref.
and remained in that position until 21 May 2012.
From May 2012 to June 2013, she served as Assistant to President Putin for Economic Affairs.
Succeeding Sergey Ignatyev in 2013, Nabiullina was appointed head of the Central Bank of Russia,
In May 2014 she was named one of the world's most powerful women by Forbes,
Euromoney magazine named her their 2015 Central Bank Governor of the Year.
In 2017, the British magazine The Banker chose Nabiullina as 'Central Banker of the Year, Europe'.
On 28 February 2022, she gave a speech announcing a number of measures to combat the 2022 Russian financial crisis
In March 2022, it was reported that she had attempted to resign her position, only to be ordered to stay in post by Putin.
In September 2022, the United States Treasury Department sanctioned Nabiullina.
In 2020, Nabiullina appeared at press conferences with a brooch of a blue wave, a dot, a tumbler, a stork.
In March 2021, when the increase in the refinancing rate was announced for the first time in three years, she appeared with a hawk.
In September 2021, Nabiullina revealed the meaning of the brooches, which represent her own way of communication, an alternate language to 'give the market a chance to reflect'.
In the late 1980s while studying at the graduate school of Moscow State University, Nabiullina married a lecturer there, Yaroslav Kuzminov.
Kuzminov became rector of National Research University Higher School of Economics (1994-2021), since July 2021 the academic supervisor of the HSE.
Kuzminov became rector of National Research University Higher School of Economics (1994-2021), since July 2021 the academic supervisor of the HSE.
They have a son, Vasiliy (born 13 August 1988), at present a Research Fellow at the HSE.
On 19 April 2022, Nabiullina was sanctioned by Australia after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
On 30 September 2022, after the Russian annexation of southern and eastern Ukraine, she was sanctioned by the United States.

Tatyana Vladimirovna Paramonova became the acting head of the Central Bank of Russia on 15 October 1994 after Viktor Gerashchenko resigned following the events on 11 October 1994 known as 'Black Tuesday'.
On 2 December 1994 during her tenure, law enforcement raided Most-Bank.
In late April 1995, Vladimir Vinogradov was very critical of Paramonova's leadership of the Central Bank and, subsequently, the Duma never approved her as the governor of the Bank of Russia.
On 24 August 1995 or 'Black Thursday', the Moscow market for interbank loans collapsed which became the basis for Paramonova stepping down as acting head of the Central Bank on 8 November 1995.
On 24 August 1995 or 'Black Thursday', the Moscow market for interbank loans collapsed which became the basis for Paramonova stepping down as acting head of the Central Bank on 8 November 1995.
Sergei Konstantinovich Dubinin replaced Paramonova and was approved by the Duma on 22 November 1995 to be the governor of the Central Bank.
Sergey Dubinin had been the acting finance minister of Russia from January 1994 until October 1994 when he was fired following the events of 'Black Tuesday'.

Tatyana Vladimirovna Paramonova (Russian: Татьяна Владимировна Парамонова; born 24 October 1950 Moscow, Soviet Union), who had been first deputy of the Central Bank since 1992, became the acting head of the Central Bank of Russia on 15 October 1994 after Viktor Gerashchenko resigned following the events on 11 October 1994 known as 'Black Tuesday'.

Tatyana Vladimirovna Paramonova (Russian: Татьяна Владимировна Парамонова; born 24 October 1950 Moscow, Soviet Union), who had been first deputy of the Central Bank since 1992, became the acting head of the Central Bank of Russia on 15 October 1994 after Viktor Gerashchenko resigned following the events on 11 October 1994 known as 'Black Tuesday'.

Sergei Konstantinovich Dubinin, who was the former deputy chairman of the board of Imperial Bank which was led by Sergey Rodionov and focused on oil and natural gas supplies to East Germany and later to Germany including the oil-for-pipes program, replaced Paramonova and was approved by the Duma on 22 November 1995 to be the governor of the Central Bank.

Sergei Konstantinovich Dubinin, who was the former deputy chairman of the board of Imperial Bank which was led by Sergey Rodionov and focused on oil and natural gas supplies to East Germany and later to Germany including the oil-for-pipes program, replaced Paramonova and was approved by the Duma on 22 November 1995 to be the governor of the Central Bank.
Sergey Dubinin had been the acting finance minister of Russia from January 1994 until October 1994 when he was fired following the events of 'Black Tuesday'.

roles.title: Central Banker
quotes: In 2017, the British magazine The Banker chose Nabiullina as 'Central Banker of the Year, Europe'.

roles.title: head of the Central Bank
quotes: There is a belief in the Russian media that the head of the Central Bank uses brooches at public events to signal the state of the economy and the regulator's plans.
the Central Bank of Russia, under her leadership, hiked interest rates, free-floated the exchange rate, and kept a cap on inflation
Russian military operation in Ukraine and annexation of Crimea
Russian military operation in Ukraine and annexation of Crimea
In the late 1980s while studying at the graduate school of Moscow State University, Nabiullina married a lecturer there, Yaroslav Kuzminov.
Kuzminov became rector of National Research University Higher School of Economics (1994-2021), since July 2021 the academic supervisor of the HSE.
Kuzminov became rector of National Research University Higher School of Economics (1994-2021), since July 2021 the academic supervisor of the HSE.
They have a son, Vasiliy (born 13 August 1988), at present a Research Fellow at the HSE.
On 19 April 2022, Nabiullina was sanctioned by Australia after the Russian invasion of Ukraine.
On 30 September 2022, after the Russian annexation of southern and eastern Ukraine, she was sanctioned by the United States.

Tatyana Vladimirovna Paramonova became the acting head of the Central Bank of Russia on 15 October 1994 after Viktor Gerashchenko resigned following the events on 11 October 1994 known as 'Black Tuesday'.
On 2 December 1994 during her tenure, law enforcement raided Most-Bank.
In late April 1995, Vladimir Vinogradov was very critical of Paramonova's leadership of the Central Bank and, subsequently, the Duma never approved her as the governor of the Bank of Russia.
On 24 August 1995 or 'Black Thursday', the Moscow market for interbank loans collapsed which became the basis for Paramonova stepping down as acting head of the Central Bank on 8 November 1995.
On 24 August 1995 or 'Black Thursday', the Moscow market for interbank loans collapsed which became the basis for Paramonova stepping down as acting head of the Central Bank on 8 November 1995.
Sergei Konstantinovich Dubinin replaced Paramonova and was approved by the Duma on 22 November 1995 to be the governor of the Central Bank.

roles.title: governor of the Central Bank
quotes: Sergei Konstantinovich Dubinin replaced Paramonova and was approved by the Duma on 22 November 1995 to be the governor of the Central Bank.

Tatyana Vladimirovna Paramonova (Russian: Татьяна Владимировна Парамонова; born 24 October 1950 Moscow, Soviet Union), who had been first deputy of the Central Bank since 1992, became the acting head of the Central Bank of Russia on 15 October 1994 after Viktor Gerashchenko resigned following the events on 11 October 1994 known as 'Black Tuesday'.

Tatyana Vladimirovna Paramonova (Russian: Татьяна Владимировна Парамонова; born 24 October 1950 Moscow, Soviet Union), who had been first deputy of the Central Bank since 1992, became the acting head of the Central Bank of Russia on 15 October 1994 after Viktor Gerashchenko resigned following the events on 11 October 1994 known as 'Black Tuesday'.

Sergei Konstantinovich Dubinin, who was the former deputy chairman of the board of Imperial Bank which was led by Sergey Rodionov and focused on oil and natural gas supplies to East Germany and later to Germany including the oil-for-pipes program, replaced Paramonova and was approved by the Duma on 22 November 1995 to be the governor of the Central Bank.

Sergei Konstantinovich Dubinin, who was the former deputy chairman of the board of Imperial Bank which was led by Sergey Rodionov and focused on oil and natural gas supplies to East Germany and later to Germany including the oil-for-pipes program, replaced Paramonova and was approved by the Duma on 22 November 1995 to be the governor of the Central Bank.
Sergey Dubinin had been the acting finance minister of Russia from January 1994 until October 1994 when he was fired following the events of 'Black Tuesday'.
